Comment:
This game features an unusual opening, an exciting middlegame, and tantalizing missed opportunity on both sides... all in all, one of my favorite games so far from the recent tournament!

I start out with e4 most of the time, but I knew my tournament opponents would likely be well-versed in the standard openings.  So I dusted off an old favorite... 1. a3?!, Anderssen's opening, after a grandmaster famous for his wild and brilliant play (he was involved in both "The Immortal Game" and "The Evergreen Game", two of the most famous games in history.)
I'd like to think Black was a bit confused by my choice of opening, but he stuck to his plan and staked a claim for the center.
My idea here was to get into a kind of reverse Sicilian, and possibly start expanding on the queenside with an eventual b4.
Fighting for control of e4.
Fighting for control of e4.
(?!) Black points at f2.  I'm not worried about Ng4?, since I still have e3! in reserve.  Also, I can now play b4 at any time to gain a tempo.
Continuing with development.
Continuing with development.
Continuing with development.
(?) I guess he didn't want me to play Bg5.  But Black has neglected his defenses...
I see no reason not to snap up Black's e-pawn.
I felt that the gain of a pawn was worth the loss in tempo, since Black hardly appears to be in a position to take advantage.
I felt that the gain of a pawn was worth the loss in tempo, since Black hardly appears to be in a position to take advantage.
More to the point would have been .. d5, opening the position and increasing pressure on my uncastled king.
Now the bishop will be driven back into the corner, allowing me to continue my development and expansion on the queenside.
Forced.

An escape hatch for the bishop.
I opted to expand before castling, to prevent Ne5 and prepare an eventual .. d5  or .. c5.

Note the connected pawns on the a and b-files.  If we wind up in an endgame, those kids are going to wind up being very powerful.

Increasing my control of the center.  I plan to follow up with .. d5 to further restrict Black's queenside.
